turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Dennis Wilburn called from Arizona to say he's faxing in the new Tidwell offer on Thursday morning, and you'll be happy.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Happy. He said "happy?"

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Actually he said "glad." _ 85.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Good.  Good.  Glad is good.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Plus, you could use that commission.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I sunk most of what I had into this condo, which devalued, and --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: You don't have to explain.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look, the other night, I want to apologize.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Yeah, what happened there.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We're two people working together and we can't have an atmosphere.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I'm relieved you said that.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I mean, the other night was... I felt like you understood something I could barely even say, something way down deep in the murk --  -- but we have a company here to think about.  I won't ever take advantage of you in that way again.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Oh good.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You walked out on a job for me, and I won't ruin that.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Exactly because I know this is a time when you need to be alone with your thoughts.  _ 86.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Wow.  That's more than a dress. That's an Audrey Hepburn movie.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Yeah -- guess I got revved up at the idea of an evening among adults -- no offense buster.  You meet Chad the nanny?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yeah, I did -- am I dressed okay? I guess I didn't realize we were...

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: We'll see you soon, honey. Bye.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Bye you guys. _ 88.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It was laziness1 my whole breakup with Avery. You know that thing you say, "it's nobody's fault." It's one of the great lies, right? Someone is always to blame -- if you go for it, go for it like you do a job, work at it --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Maybe love shouldn't be such hard work. I know, but --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Maybe you should call her.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No no no.  I just underestimated her...  her temper, I guess.  Why are we even talking about this?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Yeah.  It wasn't like my marriage to Roger was so great, even before --  Jerry?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Let's not tell our sad stories.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well -- this would be goodnight.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I think you should not come in, or come in depending on how you feel.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Same to you.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: No.  I have to go in.  I live here.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Right.  I'll come in.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Okay. Wait here a second.  Do we really want to do this?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Oh hell yes.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Oh God.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Easy, easy --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Another time, okay Dorothy?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Fine, I just --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: And I appreciate that impulse.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Sure you're okay to drive this?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: This rig? Phht.  No problem.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: So I'll see you this weekend.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Look, just in case this weekend becomes next month and next month becomes... whatever...  Don't make a joke of your life. Go back and read what you wrote. You're better than the rest of them, better than the Bob Sugars, and don't forget it.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: If I said that, would you stay?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: No no.  Don't do that.  Don't say that if you don't...

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Will you marry me?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I was thinking I hope he doesn't get injured. I felt responsible.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Sometimes I can't tell at all, what's going through that head of yours.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: And I really don't know your noises yet.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well, when you wonder, ask me.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Okay... I will...

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Why do you love me?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Why do you love me?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: It's my fault.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: It's not fair to you.  This whole --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Tell me -- let me help --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I took advantage of you and worst of all, I'm not alone. I did this with a kid.  I was just on some ride where I thought I was in 1ove enough for both of us.  I did this.  And at least I can do something about it now.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well -- I'm not the guy who's going to run.  I stick.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I don't need you to "stick."

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You want...

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I don't know --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: ...my soul or something. _ 117.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Why fucking not!  I deserve it.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Dorothy -- what if I'm just not built that way?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I think we made a mistake here.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What if it's true?  "Great at friendship bad at intimacy." I mean, come on.  It's the theme of my bachelor film --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I know.  I watched it.  I sort of know it by heart.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I don't like to give up.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Oh please.  My need to make the best of things, and your need to be what, "responsible"... if one of us doesn't say something now we might lose ten years being polite about it. Why don't we call this next road trip what it is.  A nice long break.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What about Ray?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: There's no question you'll be friends. Of course you'll be friends.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: So this break... is a break-up.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Come on, Jerry.  You know this isn't easy for me.  _ 118.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: This used to be my specialty. I was good in a living room.  Send me in there, I'll do it alone. And now I just... I don't know... but on what was supposed to be the happiest night of my business life, it wasn't complete, wasn't nearly close to being in the same vicinity as complete, because I couldn't share it with you.  I couldn't hear your voice, or laugh about it with you.  I missed my wife.  We live in a cynical world, and we work in a business of tough competitors, so try not to laugh --  I love you.  You complete me.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Aw, shut up.  You had me at hello. _ 130.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: What about medical?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Of course, medical! _ 42.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: You are a single mother.  You have given up the right to be frivolous.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: If you'd read what he wrote, you would have left with him too.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: You know how much those Well Child exams cost --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Of course I know --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Wait. Where is he?

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: He's in the living room asleep.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: He's coming over.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: At eleven at night? _ 70.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: He just lost his best client.  He called from the plane.  I invited the guy over.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Dotty -- this is not "guy.". This is a "syndrome."  It's called Early Midlife, About-To-Marry, Hanging Onto The-Bottom-Rung Dear- God-Don't-Let-Me-Be-Alone, I'll- Call-My-Newly Long-suffering- Assistant-Without Medical-For- Company Syndrome.  And if, knowing all that, you still allow him to come over, more power to you.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Honey, he's engaged.  And for the first time in my professional life, I'm a part of something I believe in.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: I heard.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: No kidding.  I looked over and saw the shadow of two curious shoes in the doorway of the kitchen.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: This guy would go home with a gardening tool right now if it showed interest.  Wait.  Use the frosted glasses.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Look, here's some of that chicken with salsa too, I warmed it up -- _ 74.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: That's the girl I love.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: But you just gotta hear me out on one thing.  You're very responsible with Ray and you know it's not right for a little boy to hear some strange man's voice in the house.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: As opposed to twenty angry women?

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: I've got a 24 hour a day reminder of Roger, for the rest of my life. I have had three lovers in four years, all boring, all achingly self-sufficient all friends of yours I might add, and all of them running a distant second to a warm bath.  Look at me, Laurel, look at me.  I'm the oldest 26 year old in the world!  How do I look?

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Forgot your keys --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: That's the first time I ever saw him kiss a man, like a dad, wasn't that just... thrilling?  I mean, he must have been needing that.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: No no.  Don't cry at the beginning of the date.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Oh, knock it off! _ 89.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: First you gotta tell me something.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: No--

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Because I'm worried that you're putting your faith in this guy who, because of the way things are going, may not have an emotional marble in his head.

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Please, if I start talking --

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Guys are just different people when they're hanging onto the bottom rung.

turns.speaker: LAUREL
turns.text: Easy, hon, I was just looking for fun details --

turns.speaker: DOROTHY
turns.text: Oh, well, why didn't you say so? And oh, I don't know if you're interested in this detail, but I was just about to tell you that I love him.  I love him, and I don't care what you think.  I love him for the guy he wants to be, and I love him for the guy he almost is. I love him.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: No, Roy.  I'm not gonna cry.

turns.speaker: FIRESTONE
turns.text: -- well, Rod, your agent passed me a note before the show. He says that your deal memo has been signed by the Arizona Cardinals. Four years for ten-point-two million dollars.  Playing in the state where you grew up.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I... I love everybody, man.  I love my wife.  My kids.  Little Tyson. My new baby Kaydee.  My brother Tee Pee. I love my friends, my teammates, who am I leaving out?

turns.speaker: FIRESTONE
turns.text: It's only a half-hour show, Rod.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Oh yes.  Jerry Maguire!  My agent! This is a fierce, loving individual, I love this man, he is love, he is about love -- my ambassador of kwan.

turns.speaker: FIRESTONE
turns.text: Ten seconds, Rod.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: And I love my fans, of which he is one. Wanna thank them for all my Sundays, and of course my Monday nights too.  That about says it...

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Matt, I came here because in all honesty your son is just another piece of cattle to SMI.  But to me --

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: We decided to stay with you.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Oh, thank you.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Told myself -- if he shows up, we'll stick with him.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You know, I'm not a hugger and yet... I can't let go.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I want him to go number one in the draft, and I want him to play.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's either going to be Denver or San Diego trading up to take him.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Denver is where he should be.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'll give it everything.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: You know I don't do "contracts." But'cha do have my word, and it's stronger than oak.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: What happened to Denver?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Denver got very silent about a day ago.  San Diego's got a fever for Cush.  This stuff tends to happen the night before a draft.  People get crazy.  And San Diego, you should know, is crazy to the tune of seven years for thirty. Signing bonus of eight.  Million.

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Not right now, Jerry.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Do I know everything there is to know here?  You fellas aren't talking with Bob Sugar, are you?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Apparently, Denver wanted to deal with him instead of you.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Said who?  Sugar?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: Hey, I'm learning as I go.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: So you empowered Bob Sugar to deal with Denver behind my back?

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: I'm sorry, I --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I brought Denver to twenty million. Denver deals with me all the time. You listened to Sugar? You let that snake in the door.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Now.  Wait.  You didn't actually sign with Sugar, did you? Tell me you didn't sign.  Because I'm still sort of moved by your "my word is stronger'n oak" thing --

turns.speaker: MATT
turns.text: We signed an hour ago.  You were in the lobby with the black fella.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Alright, we're just getting started on my list of things you need to know. Take notes if you want to.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Good, 'cause see, I am a valuable commodity.  I go across the middle. I see the ball and a dude coming right at me, wanting to kill me, I tell my brain "get killed, catch the ball." That's New York Steak, baby.  Rare. And yet, nobody's giving me LOVE. Nobody's giving me PROPS.  Nobody. I went to Arizona State, I'm from Arizona, I break Arizona records, I'm a Sun Devil, man!!!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Now you want Arizona dollars.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Exactly.  And I'm sitting here with an ant problem, look!  And my brother Tee Pee's room is flooded with water.  Say hello to Jerry Maguire --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: --  now to recap, I want to stay in Arizona, I want my new contract, I like you, you're nice to my wife, I will stay with you, that's what I'm doing for you, but here's what you're gonna do for me. You listening?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Mmm.  Hmm.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: It's a very personal, very important thing.  It's a family motto.  So I want to share it with you.  You ready?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Here it is.  "Show me the money."  Show.  Me.  The.  Money. _ 36.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I got it.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Now doesn't that just make you feel good to say it?  Say it with me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Show.  Me.  The.  Money.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Congratulations.  You're still my agent.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: At last I find you.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Why the fuck am I here?  I feel like I'm five years late for the Prom.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I came all the way here for that? To walk the lobby?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yeah.  And it might have even worked too.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Let's do it again.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You believe they're shooting a Nike ad down there?  Did I ever tell you my Nike story?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I gotta get back to Cushman.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Okay, I understand.  I'll boil it down for ya.  Fuck Nike.  All they do is ignore me...

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You're loving me now, aren't ya?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'm not about love -- I'm about "showing you the money."

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Good.  I was just testing ya.  But just you saying that? Makes me love ya.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Get some sleep.  See you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Sure you don't want to go out and find some karoake?  I'm a very good singer, man --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Call me tomorrow.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I might call you later!

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You love me now, don't you?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Very much.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Rod --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You feel bad you tested positive? Quit doing blow!  You feel bad about your baby girl? Why did you leave the mother?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What are you doing with me, Rod?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Don't you even see -- I'm finished. I'm fucked. Twenty-four hours ago, I was hot. Now... I'm a cautionary tale!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: See this jacket I'm wearing?  You like it?  I don't really need it, because I'm CLOAKED IN FAILURE. I lost the number one draft pick the night before the draft. They will teach my story to other agents on "do not do this" day in agent school. Why? Let's recap. Because a hockey player's kid made me feel like a superficial jerk, I had two slices of bad pizza, went to bed, grew a conscience and wrote a 25-page Manifesto of Doom!

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Well, boo-fucking-hoo.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: The least you could do is nod and act sympathetic --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's a quality that might come in handy for a commercial sometime. _ 69.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You are not allowed to act this way.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Man, I got a shelf life of ten years, tops!  My next contract's gotta bring me the dollars that'11 last me and mine a very long time. I'm out of this sport in five years.  What's my family gonna live on? What you get me.  So I don't want to hear about ya shit, your "nya nya nya."

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Another drink please.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Anybody else would have left you by now, but I'm sticking with you. I said I would. And if I got to ride your ass like Zorro, you're gonna show me the money.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Oh my God.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Did you tell him about the "ten million for four years?"

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Uh, not today, but --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: John Taylor.  J.J. Stokes.  Andre Rison.  I SMOKE all these fools, and yet they're making the big sweet dollars. They're making the money, and I got an agent that ain't even put the number on the table.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I understand your anxiety.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Maybe you don't.  Because it's not just the money I deserve.  It's not just the "coin."  It's the...

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: --  the kwan.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That's your word?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Yeah, man, it means love, respect, community... and the dollars too. The package.  The kwan.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But how did you get "kwan?" _ 82.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I got there from "coin," dude. Coin, coin... kwaaaan.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Great word.  Towel?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: No, I air-dry.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Rod, I say this with great respect, but those players you mentioned are marquee players and --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Is that your porty or mine?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You're telling me to dance.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No, I'm saying to be --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: "Love me love me love me... put me on t.v."  That's the iconography of rascism, man!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Rod, I'm not a rascist.  I'm telling you to be the best version of you, to get back to the guy who first started playing this game. Way back when you were a kid.  It wasn't just about the money, was it?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Do your job, man, don't tell me to dance.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: What's wrong.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Forget it.  Forget it.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: No tell me. _ 84.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'm out here for you!  You don't know what it's like to be me out here for you. It is an up-at-dawn pride-swallowing seige that I will never fully tell you about! Okay?! Help me help you help me help you.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You're hanging by a very thin thread, dude.  And I dig that about you.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: If you get injured, you get nothing.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Won't happen.  I'm strong in my mind.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's a risk.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'll get you some quick work --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Good deal, man.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Dude, know your art form.  If you put the camera down here, looking up, I look more powerful.  There's no need for a camel... you got ME.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Rod, get on the camel.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Can I ask you a question totally unrelated to your career?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Oh, we gonna be friends now?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What do you know about dating a single mother?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Oh I know plenty.  I was raised by a single mother.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Tell me, because it's been a month, and she's about to take another job in San Diego.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: First, single mothers don't "date." They have been to the circus, you know what I'm saying? They have been to the puppet show and they have seen the strings. You love her?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: How do I know?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You know when you know.  It makes you shivver, it eats at your insides. You know?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No, I don't know.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Then you gotta have The Talk.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But I sure don't like that she's leaving.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Well, that ain't fair to her.  A single mother, that's a sacred thing, man. _ 103.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: The kid is amazing.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: No.  A real man does not shoplift the "pooty" from a single mom.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I didn't "shoplift the pooty."  We were thrown together and -- I mean it's two mutual people who --  Alright, I shoplifted the pooty.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Shame on you.  SHAME on you.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You never had The Talk, did you?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Well, this was another way to go.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Tidwell moves to a tan in a wheelchair, signs an autograph and moves on.  Jerry alongside. The quarterback sucks, man.  He's gonna get me killed.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'm a little worried --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I'm worried too.  I'm worried that the only reason I'm here getting my brains blown loose is that you weren't asshole enough to get my ten million three months ago.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We can still take the offer, Rod.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well, just stay healthy. I will show you the kwan.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Hey, that's my word, okay?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I'm gonna have the game of my life on Monday Night Football, and show all these motherfuckers.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Take care, okay? You're my entire client roster.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Don't I know.  Now go home to your wife.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Why are you even here, man? You could have told me all this over the phone.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I don't know -- how's "dedication" for an answer?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: You don't want to go home, do you?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Why are you doing this to me, Rod?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I'm asking you a question --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No, you're --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I'm trying to talk to you.  How's your marriage?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Not everyone has what you have.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Then why'd you get married?  I'm asking you as a friend.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You're jabbing at me. _ 112.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I'm sorry I asked.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No, I'm going to answer you.  You want an answer?  I'll give it to you.  Loyalty.  She was loyal.  Everything grew from there.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: That's an answer.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Damn right.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: For loyalty, you buy a dog.  For love, you get married.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look.  I'm happy to entertain you, as always, but I have a question for you.  Are we really "friends?"

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Why not --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well, friends can tell each other anything, right? If we have our "friends" hats on --

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Airight.  Here's why you don't have your ten million dollars yet. You are a paycheck player.  You play with your head.  Not your heart.  In your personal life?  Heart. But when you get on the field --  _ 113.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: I don't want to be friends anymore.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Beautiful.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We still having dinner in L.A.?

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Only 'cause my wife likes your wife!

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Jerry!  You made it --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Go.  Flee.

turns.speaker: TIDWELL
turns.text: Thanks for coming.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I missed ya.  What can I say?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I have to ask.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: What --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Where'd you find the perfect white shirt?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You're with the sports people on the plane, right?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Jerry Maguire.  SMI.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Bobbi Fallon.  BPI.  I'm producing the Coke commercials for the playoffs.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well.  Good luck with that --

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: And I can't say his name without laughing I want to eat him up. I want to say goodbye to every bad thought I ever had about relationships.  I mean, I crave this guy... and yet... why... why did I have that affair this weekend?  Does that mean I'm not in love with my boyfriend?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I think you'll know when you see him at the gate.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: It's the death rattle of my singlehood, right? Because I finally see the white picket fence looming and I love it/hate it/love it/hate it/ love it... you're right, I'll know when I see him. Why is it so easy to talk with you?!  Tell me about your fiancee.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I uh... don't think we're quite at your pitch yet.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Tell me, and then you can sleep.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: She's an NFL publicist... amazing sense of style... former athlete... volleyball... world class... really knows how to live every moment of her life, which is why I should take a nap now...

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Oh, tell the story.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: --so our first date, she told me about her favorite place in the world, the seven pools of Hana on the island of Maui...

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Gorgeous.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: A year-and-a-half later, we were both in Hawaii for the Pro Bowl. Now I've always hit a wall at 18 months.  Every serious girlfriend lasts 18 months.  It's like --ka- boom.  The curse of 18 months.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: That's when you need to cement, and define define define.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Exactly.  And the world does not need another 35 year-old bachelor. I knew I wanted to propose, so I took her there.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: To the pools?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: To the pools.  Now she's Miss Rock Climber, and I'm more the Non-Rock Climber, but we're hiking up through the pools and there's a fine mist in the air, and I have the ring in my pocket, and I'm a little nervous, I'm lagging behind, and she says to me, get this -- "Hurry up, klutz."

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Oh no -- _ 14.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well, it bothered me somewhat. And I got quiet.  And now she's quiet and we're both pouting a little, you know.  And I decide I'm not going to propose.  The mood is not right. Why be impulsive? Now at this point I know she knows that I was going to propose and didn't.  And she knows I know.  So the entire sixty mile ride back to the airport, we don't speak. And we're both good at that.  We fly to Honolulu in silence.  We check into the Pro Bowl hotel --

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: How sad --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But wait...

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Which they do.  And we're standing there. All the football guys are in the lobby, watching, there's even an ESPN crew.  So I turn to her and sort of grandly say, "Well, this is me, Klutz, asking you, Goddess of Rock Climbing, to marry me." And I took out the ring, and I don't much like big scenes, but she said "yes" right there in the lobby and some of the toughest men in football wept like babies.  We're getting married in February.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Jerry.  You two will be together forever.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Marcee.  How's my favorite player's wife?

turns.speaker: MARCEE
turns.text: Jerry, Rod is very very upset. Tyson, no!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: How can I make your life better?

turns.speaker: MARCEE
turns.text: I know you say to take the Arizona offer, but my husband needs more recognition.  _ 25.

turns.speaker: MARCEE
turns.text: You gonna get that --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Not a chance.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Marcee, things are changing around here.  You and Rod will have my total personal attention.

turns.speaker: MARCEE
turns.text: Damn right, and you can start by taking Rod's poster and putting it where people can see it!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Damn right.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'll go back to them.

turns.speaker: MARCEE
turns.text: And say what?  "Please remove your dick from my ass?!"

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Okay, we don't take this emotionally. We roll with this problem.

turns.speaker: MARCEE
turns.text: What are you talking about -- "don't get emotional." If you ask me, you haven't gotten emotional ENOUGH about this man. _ 98.
